awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Novel Applications of Mobile Observational Strategies to Non-Severe Atmospheric Scenarios
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at Jackson State University seeks to collect multi-scale meteorological data with mobile observing systems and perform the data analysis of atmospheric environments at scales never before sampled. The project provides research experiences for undergraduate students. This project is funded by the Division of Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research in the Directorate for Geosciences.

This project seeks to substantially expand the realm of applications for mobile observations to geographic and phenomenological settings that essentially remain "unexplored territory" at scales that are unsampled by fixed in situ observing systems. Because mobile observations sampled at high frequency can readily detect spatial variations on scales ranging from tens of meters to hundreds of kilometers regardless of cloud or precipitation conditions, they can uniquely fill in gaps between fixed stations in order to bridge atmospheric scales from microscale to synoptic scale. The research will conduct and analyze a wide variety of mobile transects in all seasons and in collaboration with researchers at with  University of Missouri at Columbia. Cases are expected to focus on baroclinic zones, moisture boundaries, and microscale variability. Primary raw data products will be temperature and humidity sampled at 2 second  intervals. The surface transects will be supplemented where appropriate with lower tropospheric radiosonde launches.

por.por_cntn:
This project was developed in response to an initiative of the NSF to strengthen research capacity of faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). The primary impetus was to extend the capabilities and applications of mobile meteorological measurements across different scales and environments, while generally developing the observational research capacity of the meteorology program at Jackson State University (an HBCU).

 

Integrated mobile observing systems were customized through the project for use on a passenger automobile, pedestrian backpack, and a 17-foot sea kayak. These are able to measure temperature, humidity, pressure, and related quantities over a very wide range of scales and in locations where such measurements are not normally practical. Similar systems have been used before mainly to study urban climate and severe thunderstorms. We have demonstrated their use in a much broader range of applications, including forest microclimates, frontal systems, drylines, the Southwest U.S. monsoon, and sea breezes. Improved methods have been advanced for measurement and analysis of these data.

 

We used the vehicle observing platform to collect data in 23 states, including transects across 27 fronts and 4 drylines. The temperatures ranged from 11 F to 110 F, at elevations ranging from 200 feet below sea level to 11,600 feet above sea level. The pedestrian backpack system was used on 20 days in three different states. Additionally, this observational capacity enabled participation in field campaigns led by other universities: 

  • CHEESEHEAD19 in 2019 with vehicle, backpack, kayak: Surface climate processes in northern Wisconsin (separate NSF funding; not included in counts; led by Univ. of Wisconsin) 
  • CBREESE2 in 2018 with vehicle: Sea breeze thunderstorms in Florida (led by Embry-Riddle Aeronautical Univ.) 
  • MMEME in 2017 with vehicle: Solar eclipse in Missouri (separate NASA funding; not included in counts; led by Univ. of Missouri) 
  • (SWEX was planned for 2020 in California with vehicle to study fire weather conditions, but was delayed to 2022 due to COVID19 pandemic. Led by Univ. of California at Santa Barbara.) 

 

Through the project, approximately 20 African-American undergraduate students have gained experience with research meteorological data collection and analysis. Public outreach events have impacted more than 50 secondary school students (mostly from underrepresented minorities). Graduate students at four other universities were engaged through seminars and data collection.
